page.title: 14BRAYDON FARMING GENERAL
page.content: The land is very heavy clay and so difficult to work. In farming language it is "man's land" and not "boys land". This factor keeps farms small. Dairy farms are approx 50-100 acres. The land type makes it impossible to stock these farms intensively as the ground gets so boggy in winter and grass is slow to grow in spring due to the cold and wet. Most farms are family concerns with very little outside labour. Contract- ors may be brought in for hay/silage making and hedgecutting. The straw has to be bought-in from surrounding arable areas. Farmers often buy it off the field, baling and carting it home themselves. There are some wealthy landowners with outside business interests and they will employ managers to run the farm.
